newsitem.title: CANADA: Arakis CEO says pipeline process to start.
newsitem.headline: Arakis CEO says pipeline process to start.

text.p: Arakis Energy Corp, with a signed deal for its Sudan oil project now under its belt, planned this week to start finding construction companies to build a pipeline, the company's chief executive said on Monday.
"We have got a very aggressive schedule. We're planning to go out for prequalifications within the next few days," Arakis's John McLeod said.
The prequalification will be held to hammer down a list of companies, or groups of firms, that have the ability to construct the 1,500-km line.
Bidding for the project's construction was slated to start in April and construction by the end of this year, McLeod said.

He said the line, to extend to the Red Sea from the firm's oilfields in southern Sudan, would initially be equipped to ship 150,000 barrels of oil a day by the end of 1999, but woulds be expandable to 250,000 BPD.
McLeod confirmed earlier on Monday that Arakis and its partners in the US$1 billion project signed the final agreement for the development in Khartoum on Saturday.

Under the 25-year agreement -- which was much anticipated by investors -- Arakis has 25 percent, China National Petroleum Corp 40 percent, Malaysia state oil company Petronas 30 percent and the Sudan government five percent.
The deal was initially announced in early December after more than a year of controversy and failed attempts to finance the project in the civil strife-torn African nation.
The consortium plans to develop the project through a joint operating company, which McLeod said would likely be ready to take over operatorship in June.
McLeod that that the company planned to begin easing into other projects, now that the Sudan development appeared to be well under way.
The company plans to drill a well in Oman in April.
"We are looking in other areas of the world. We're looking at late-stage exploration and early-stage development or a production enhancement-type project," he said.
"We're looking at something that's close to cash flow or somewhere where you can...take a rig in, start drilling and start selling oil."
